title: Resistive Force - Stone Dropped From Cliff

content.description:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A student is holding a stone of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> at rest at a height <math alttext="h equals h sub c" overflow="scroll"> <mi>h</mi> <mo>=</mo> <msub> <mi>h</mi> <mi>c</mi> </msub> </math> above the surface of a deep pool of water, as shown in the figure. The student drops the stone into the water. Resistive forces as the stone falls in the air are negligible. As the stone falls through the water, the water exerts a resistive force <math alttext="F sub W" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></msub></math> on the stone. The magnitude of the force the water exerts on the stone is modeled by <math alttext="F sub W, end sub, equals B plus k v" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>v</mi></math>, where <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> and <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> are positive constants and is the speed of the stone.

The following times describe the motion of the stone after it is released from rest.

At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the student releases the stone from rest.

At time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, the stone is at height <math alttext="one half h sub c" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>h</mi><mi>c</mi></msub></math> above the surface of the water.

At time <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, the stone reaches the surface of the water, which is at height <math alttext="h equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, is traveling with speed <math alttext="v sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, where <math alttext="v sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is greater than the terminal velocity of the stone in water. 

At time <math alttext="t sub 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, the stone reaches its terminal velocity in the water.
